Using polars for the first time

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

I finally found an excuse to try polars (thanks to Ben for showing me the light). 

For the uninitiated, polars is essentially a (much) faster version of pandas. 🐻‍❄️ > 🐼 

After using it for a recent project, here are 3 things I liked about it 👇 

1) The Syntax 

Most of the syntax is identical to pandas, which made it super easy to use without any tutorials. 
2) The “Lazy” API This allows you to manipulate dataframes without loading them into memory. 

At the end, you can perform all the operations via the .collect() method. 
3) .scan_parquet() 

Yes, you can import .parquet files in pandas, but when combined with the Lazy API, this allows you to locally work with 10X bigger datasets in polars than pandas

What’s less common, however, is automating these pipelines so data can be pulled on a schedule or event ⏲️ 

👉 In a recent Towards Data Science article, I discussed two ways we can automate data pipelines for machine learning. 

Way 1) Orchestration Tools i.e. Airflow et al. 

Way 2) Python + Triggers i.e. “The Old Fashioned Way”

I’m quitting consulting to focus on YouTube. 

Here’s why. 👇 

1) YouTube is working! (80% of my traffic comes from YT) 

2) It allows me to focus on one thing (i.e. avoid distractions) 

3) Making 1 video a week gives me a clear, quantifiable goal that I can use to frame my learning and product development. 

While committing to one thing is scary (especially something unpredictable like YouTube 😅), it is also necessary for success. 

The reason (IMO) is that commitment backs you into a corner, forcing you to innovate and learn new things.

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
What does a data scientist (actually) do? Share Tik Tok

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

12 years ago, “Data Scientist” was the sexiest job of the century. 

Today, it’s still an in-demand role, offering cushy salaries… 

But what do they actually do? 

In my view, the main job of a data scientist is to answer questions using data. 

This consists of 4 key activities 👇 

1) Have a question to answer—this typically comes from clients and business stakeholders. 

2) Acquiring the relevant data—this is the boring yet most important part. 

3) Analyzing data—once the data are in a usable form, data scientists use tools like Python or R to compute statistics and create data visualizations. 

4) Build models—we can use data to construct predictive models to solve problems and support decision-making.

Communication challenges for data scientist. Promote blog post

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

This is why data scientists don’t get promoted (hint: It’s not SWE) 👇 

A universal challenge for data scientists is communicating effectively with non-technical stakeholders. 

This was one of the biggest limiting factors for those seeking advancement when I worked at a larger enterprise. 

Here are 3 Communication tips that helped me get ahead as a data scientist. 

1) Use Stories—framing communication as 3-part narrative helps it go down easier e.g. status quo, problem, solution. 

2) Use Examples—examples make abstract ideas concrete. For instance, a 3-part narrative was used in this post. 

3) Use analogies—analogies help us learn new things by mapping the unfamiliar to the familiar, which is very handy when explaining technical ideas. 

👉 I share 4 more tips in the blog in a recent article published in Towards Data Science 

Check it out and let me know how you’ve improved your communication skills.

Fine-tuning is when we take an existing model and tweak it for a specific use case 🔧

Although this is a simple (and powerful) idea, applying it to LLMs isn’t always straightforward. 

The key challenge is that LLMs are (very) computationally expensive e.g. full fine-tuning of a 70B parameter model requires over 1TB of memory! 

👉 In my latest blog, I break down QLoRA, an approach that makes fine-tuning an LLM something you can do on your laptop. 

Check it out and let me know what you think 👇 

🔗 Link: https://lnkd.in/gsdeCVCB 

Thanks to Towards Data Science for publishing this post and all the others in my LLM series!
